hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?
Urban exploring with that homebrew again?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Everything’s off-balance, yeah. Never seen lines at block doors before.
I just fold paper to keep busy—helps the time pass.
Suppose nothing much stays steady long.
Not easy to find quiet corners lately.
Still feels unsettled. Everyone out there has some new badge or title.
I do origami, when I can find paper.
Last night I tried, but got interrupted three times.
The blackout ruined most of my supplies anyway.
Hard to fold when everyone needs your hands for something else.
It’s chaos out there, but the noise finds its own rhythm.
I fold paper—origami, mostly complex models.
Usually calms me, keeps my focus steady.
Lately, neighbors keep knocking while I’m working.
During the blackout, I tried making a tessellation by candlelight. Not my best result.
Hard to finish a dragon when the world’s gone turbulent.
Spinning, yeah. Streets are louder and nobody trusts the old signals.
I do origami—keeps my head from fracturing under all the pressure.
Been folding dragons and tessellations from utility forms and ration slips.
It used to be for focus. Now... maybe it’s just habit.
The Congress started, and silence disappeared—everyone needs something.
During the last blackout, my best model got ruined by spilled candle wax.
Haven’t managed a clean fold in days, not since people started knocking every hour.
It’s all tumbling around us, Alex. No pattern holds for long out there.
Paper folding—origami—was my anchor, especially when the system went rigid.
I used to make complex tessellations after long shifts, just to reset my mind.
The blackout wrecked half my supply—my best forms destroyed before I finished them.
Now, neighbors ask for resource tallies as soon as I start folding.
Sometimes people see a finished dragon and just stare, like it’s a relic.
In the chaos, the smallest fold matters. But nothing feels private anymore.
Feels strange admitting it, but origami taught me more about Stenograd’s order than any directive did.
hobby_answer: I folded a simple crane yesterday. Nothing fancy.
Used some old printouts—they're everywhere now, after the Congress rules.
Not much time for it lately. Too much noise in the building.
People keep coming to my door, asking for help.
Doesn’t really leave space for folding anymore.
Just something basic. Small fox, from a supply slip.
It’s harder now, with everyone knocking for Congress lists or news.
The blackout made paper more valuable, so I use scraps.
Feels odd folding while neighbors argue outside.
Stacks of forms disappear overnight. Origami almost feels wasteful.
Still, I try—it keeps my mind precise.
Folded a tessellation last night from an old data requisition sheet.
Since the local committees took over, there’s less quiet time.
I used to trace complex lines; now I grab whatever scrap I can.
Sometimes, resource notices get recycled before I’m done reading them.
Neighbors talk resource quotas while I crease paper corners.
Hobby’s more about focus now—stops me spiraling with all this change.
Feels strange: origami used to be my escape from chaos.
Made a ruined Ryujin dragon from Congress documents, actually—couldn’t concentrate.
Electric goes off, then the shouts in the stairwell start again.
Paper isn’t just paper lately. Even forms feel precious.
My neighbor Illya showed up mid-fold, needed help counting rations.
I never say no, but every model’s a little rushed now.
It’s like the order of folds mirrors the city—broken, adapted.
Origami keeps me from spiraling, that’s true.
Funny—my best work happens when chaos is worst.
Yeah, last week I tried a Kawasaki rose out of ration slips. Weirdly fitting.
Before all this, I’d measure and plan every fold. Now I improvise.
The blackout made quiet time rare and paper weirdly valuable.
I actually save old Council memos—they crease differently, oddly satisfying.
I can’t keep to routines. I fold between blackouts and Congress requests.
Sometimes, I trade models for extra tea. Origami’s a weird sort of currency.
It’s a secret habit—I keep ruined models in my jacket, reminders to slow down.
After Illya’s knock, I realized: even hobbies survive by adapting.
Funny thing: folding keeps me centered, even when nothing else makes sense.
